titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Archibald L. Parsons U.S. Navy commission 2006.034
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Nicholas Pavlik and John Zarrillo
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-03-21T15:05-0400

did.unittitle: Archibald L. Parsons U.S. Navy commission
did.abstract: Commission issued to Archibald L. Parsons by the administration of United States President Woodrow Wilson, appointing him a Civil Engineer with the rank of Commander in the U.S. Navy. Dated 1917.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Archibald L. Parsons U.S. Navy commission, 2006.034, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Finding aid draft produced by Nicholas Pavlik in 2011. Finding aid completed by John Zarrillo in 2014.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Gift of Robert Vadheim, date unknown. Formally accessioned in 2006.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Archibald L. Parsons was a civil engineer who was Assistant Chief of the Bureau of Yards and Docks during WWI. He was also head of the Bureau's Division of Design, which prepared plans and specifications for all public works of the Navy. He was stationed at the League Island Navy Yard in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In the 1920s, he worked on public works projects in Haiti. By the 1930s, he was stationed as a Public Works officer in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. He died in Brooklyn on September 24, 1953.
